ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developing research projects, and writing them in steps. Approaching datasets from multiple theoretical perspectives. Reading papers faster.

topics in phonological theory, especially Optimality Theory; theoretical phonological hypothesis development, hypothesis testing, argumentation; presentation of my and others' work; working with grammars; typology of phonological systems

I learned a lot about phonological methods, and I got a great introduction to ongoing research in phonology. The course is a natural continuation of Phonology I, and I was introduced to Optimality Theory. I got more comfortable with writing phonology papers (and linguistics papers in general).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: engaging classes/lectures; flexibility: very responsive to student interests/questions; good balance between breadth of topics and depth of coverage; semester-long development of final project led to better project and less stressful end-of-semester
The course is well-designed, and the discussions were enjoyable and lively. The environment was collaborative, and Professor Weber was very understanding and open-minded.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would recommend this course to anyone who would like to get introduced to Phonology, I can't think of a better way!
yes. for people with various levels of interest in linguistics and phonology, the class is fun, interesting, and useful

I would recommend the course to other students interested in learning more about phonology. The course is a deep-dive into current scholarship in the field, and any phonology student would be remiss to pass on an opportunity to take the course.
